title: 106_s3275
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian Fissile Materials Disposition Loan Guarantee Act of 2000". Congress finds that the proliferation of nuclear weapons poses a national security risk to the United States. Countries seeking nuclear capabilities need technical expertise and materials, which the former Soviet Union's nuclear complex possesses. Current programs address the potential loss of expertise and materials. Progress on agreements like the Highly Enriched Uranium Agreement and Plutonium Disposition Agreement will enhance US security against nuclear proliferation. Additional progress in securing and disposing of nuclear materials would further enhance US security. A program to secure and dispose of nuclear weapons materials of the former Soviet Union, including a proposal for the Russian Federation to place materials under safeguards in exchange for loans for nonproliferation programs. This initiative aims to enhance the economy of Russia and global security interests. SEC. 3. LOAN GUARANTEES. The Secretary of Energy, with the President's approval, can guarantee loans to the Russian Federation for nuclear nonproliferation programs. The total guaranteed loan principal cannot exceed $1 billion at any time, with interest covered up to 3 percent. Eligible loans are those from private lenders to the Russian government for specified purposes. The Government of the Russian Federation can receive guaranteed loans for nuclear nonproliferation programs or energy infrastructure development. Loans must be in increments of $20,000,000 and cannot be used for activities under the Plutonium Disposition Agreement. The loan principal must be in $20,000,000 increments with a minimum term of 15 years. Payments start 5 years after dispersal, with semi-annual payments thereafter. The loan proceeds will be dispersed to the Ministry of Atomic Energy of the Russian Federation. In case of default, the lender can exercise an option. The Government of the Russian Federation must provide weapons-usable plutonium and highly enriched uranium as security for each $20,000,000 loan increment. The Government of the Russian Federation must place enriched uranium under IAEA safeguards as security for a loan, which will remain under safeguards indefinitely. In case of default, the lender can use the materials to repay the loan. The Government of the Russian Federation must place enriched uranium under IAEA safeguards as security for a loan. The materials cannot be removed from safeguards during disposition or utilization. Materials under safeguards are not part of the weapons-grade plutonium to be used by Russia. Guarantees for loans are not considered contributions under the Plutonium Disposition Agreement. The Secretary is prohibited from collecting fees. The Secretary is prohibited from collecting fees for guaranteeing loans under this section. SEC. 4. $15,000,000 annually for International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations for loan guarantees and administration costs under the Act for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. Amounts remain available until expended. SEC. 6. Definitions. The Act defines terms such as Highly Enriched Uranium Agreement, Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, and Plutonium Disposition Agreement. The United States signed the Plutonium Disposition Agreement on September 1, 2000, designating plutonium as no longer required for defense purposes. The Secretary of Energy's authority to guarantee loans under this Act will end on December 31, 2003, but guarantees made before that date will remain valid.
